meanings.definition: Treat or regard as of lesser importance than something else.
meanings.sent1: She subordinated her own needs to help her friend.
meanings.sent2: In the military, lower-ranking officers are often subordinated to higher-ranking ones.
meanings.sent3: The cat subordinated its desire for a nap to chase after a butterfly.
meanings.sent4: His ambition was subordinated to his love for his family.
meanings.sent5: The student subordinated social activities to focus on studying for the exam.

meanings.definition: Place in a lower rank or position.
meanings.sent1: The manager subordinated the new employee to a senior staff member.
meanings.sent2: The teacher subordinated the troublemaker to the back of the classroom.
meanings.sent3: The chef subordinated the dessert to the main course, much to the disappointment of the diners.
meanings.sent4: The sun subordinated the moon in the sky, casting a bright light over the night.
meanings.sent5: The coach subordinated the substitute player to the starting lineup for the important game.

meanings.definition: Make subservient to or dependent on something else.
meanings.sent1: The company subordinated its success to the demands of the market.
meanings.sent2: The ruler subordinated his subjects to his every command.
meanings.sent3: The plant subordinated its growth to the limited sunlight it received.
meanings.sent4: The artist subordinated his creativity to the expectations of his patrons.
meanings.sent5: The dog subordinated its playtime to wait patiently for its owner to return home.
